text:
Hi.
Nameservers are points to the place you manage your domains. So if nameservers of the domain are pointed to A2 Hosting, it simply means that they can manage DNS on A2 Hosting. However, if they pay specifically for server hosting, and they only have a HubSpot website now, that’s unneccessary.

It’s not possible to manage DNS in HubSpot.
When using the content search api - how do you find the content id Parameter? I'm not sure what that is - or how to find it

Anyone else having issues with HubSpot loading changes to modules correctly? Co-worker and I are working on a project and are making changes to a module, when loading it onto a page and making page level edits, it is not taking the changes we made at the module level prior. sometimes it just disappears all together.
It means page ID, blog post ID, HubDB row ID, etc.
is this required - because I want the search to search the entire website/blog and landing pages

hi all,
i’d bet this question was asked a lot in the past, but i didn’t find so i’ll try my luck: is there any way to use HubSpot smart content in 3rd party cms like typo3?
use the search your site endpoint not the indexed properties one
Also, right now the beta version of the API requires authentication - so serverless functions would be needed. If you don’t have access to serverless, then I suggest using the old API for now.
where do I find the old api docs <@U7SL518D6>?
at the top of all of our beta pages we link off to the old version of the APIs. specifically for the CMS search it’s <https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/content/search-for-content>
how long should I use the old stuff?
There is no sunset date announced and the beta version of the API is still in Beta. We will announce the dates of API sunsets with plenty of heads up to enable folks to upgrade.

FWIW, I've been having an ongoing discussion with HubSpot support about this but seems nothing is going to happen. They even set up a page in Heroku that responses with 71 bytes and uses about a second to do that from where they're testing, and came to conculusion:

> In this case, they are inclined to believe that using the curl command test, having a load time of over one second is not consider a high page load time on a page that only has a h1 tag.
